posts.name: schleprock
posts.cooked:
vividhosting now says that teams can connect to the VH-109 and use an unmanaged switch to talk to the access point VH-109. other than an image: image 768×459 82.3 KB

image 768×459 82.3 KB

image 768×459 82.3 KB

there is very little documentation on this. so, a couple of questions:

Has anyone been able to get this working using an unmanaged switch?

did you have to use a specific unmanaged switch or will any giga bit switch work?

if you did get it working, is there a DHCP server (either the AP VH-109 or the robot VH-109)?

thanks, bill

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Theres nothing special here. With the radio using Radio Variant firmware, set to AP mode this setup just works. Any unmanaged switch will work.

Note that you don’t need the switch here. You could plug into the DS port, and also the 2 Aux ports on the AP. You also could hook into the LAN port on the PoE adapter, and get a 4th port. So you only need the switch if you either need more then 4 wired devices, or you need them to all be gigabit (Only the DS port on the radio is gigabit).

posts.name: ehochstein
posts.cooked:
We have our VH-109 setup in our shop exactly as outlined in that image. We have our DS and multiple programming laptops hooked up to the unmanaged switch.

Yes.

We just used a spare unmanaged switch that we had lying around, no specific requirements.

I know nothing about DHCP, so I can’t help you here.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
schleprock:

is there a DHCP server (either the AP VH-109 or the robot VH-109)?

Yes. You should not need to configure static addresses on either side for this configuration.

(I don’t trust dhcp and prefer static addressing everything on the robot, ymmv)

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

(I don’t trust dhcp and prefer static addressing everything on the robot, ymmv)

Same. On 1538’s robots we static EVERYTHING in the event we have some kind of power failure on a device or subsystem.

Ain’t nobody got time to wait for a DHCP offer when a match is only so long.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.custom_user_title: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.name: schleprock
posts.cooked:
a big thanks to everytone that responded, very much appreciated. given that this setup works and one of the VH-109’s is a dhcp server my plan is to use a wireless router/switch with wifi 5 with it’s dhcp server disabled. we’ll plug the wireless switch into the access point and should then be able to connect to the wireless router and have access to the VH-109 network, and ultimately the roborio. everything is going wireless these days and to have to plug an ethernet cable into this rig for it to work is ridiculous. it appears there was little thought put into making this work for teams when they are not at a competition, very disappointing.

yes, i agree that everything that access the network has a static IP address. but i do not want to have to assign static addresses to the laptops that connect to the robot.

we bought wifi 5 dongles for all of our laptops a few years ago. this allows us to be connected to the robot and the internet at the same time. this allows us to use VS code live share and have multiple students/mentors connected to the robot while also being able to see the code being edited live and help out the students that are programming.

anyway, i’ll reply to this thread on how it works out.

thanks,

bill

posts.name: schleprock
posts.cooked: we have successfully setup the vh-109 radios (robot and access point) with an old DLink DIR-842 wireless AC1200 router. i turned off the DHCP server on the wireless router and plugged the access point vh-109 radio ( DS port) into one of the LAN ethernet ports on the DLink. i setup the wireless router’s ip address as one that “shouldn’t” get used by the vh-109 (in our case i used 10.46.8.251). so now we can wirelessly access the robot with the new radios by connecting to the DLink. it seems to work well until the access point vh-109 overheats. the biggest issue is that the access point vh-109 overheats… we wire tied the vh-109 to a large piece of aluminum scrap that is used for the robot frame. but it still overheats. when it does overheat we get disconnected from the robot repeatedly. guess we’ll need to put a fan on it. poor design to say the least… one other thing, you have to put some space (about 3 feet) between the access point and the wireless router. it appears that the vh-109 radio puts out a …load of radiation that interferes with the wireless router’s 5GHz band.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
schleprock:

but it still overheats. when it does overheat we get disconnected from the robot repeatedly. guess we’ll need to put a fan on it. poor design to say the least…

The VH-109 was not designed to be an always on 6GHz access point. WCP does sell a heat sync and fan kit for the VH-109 to resolve this though https://wcproducts.com/products/wcp-1822

You could also pick up a VH-113 that has a built in heat sync and fan. https://wcproducts.com/products/wcp-0395

link_counts.title: Radio Heatsink (For at Home Practice) – WestCoast Products

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Our VH-109 seems to work fine over a long period as a 6 GHz AP, but we put it down on a giant aluminum block that sinks away nearly all of the heat (the back plate doesn’t feel like it’s much above room temperature after an hour or two, though the front is pretty warm). You could also just see if the 2.4 GHz AP mode works in your environment, and if it does, remove both the DLink and the second VH-109 from the equation entirely.

You can also use Wi-Fi 6E capable dongles to connect to the VH-109 6 GHz AP and avoid the DLink, though obviously you’ll need to solve the heat issue for that to work (and, at present, not cheap).

schleprock:

it appears there was little thought put into making this work for teams when they are not at a competition, very disappointing.

Thought was put in. From public comments they’ve made, it was determined that what’s best for home use was at odds with what was best for actual competition use without making the device even more expensive (and it’s already more expensive than FRC teams would probably like).

Personally, I agree with the decision to prioritize connectivity in real matches, as that’s what we have least control over and can’t get back if things go wrong. There are many solutions available if a given at-home setup isn’t working for you - including swapping out the VH-109 on the robot for a different radio at home.

For example, if you can figure out where to put it, you can just mount the DLink on the robot, power it with a 12V regulator like the VRM , and wire it either directly to the network components on the robot (with a DHCP server active) or just to the VH-109 already on the robot (being sure to leave the DHCP server on the DLink off). You could also use an OM5P from last year to accomplish the same thing.
